ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: NeuroBlast
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Derek but from what you ve said it all sounds a bit odd. Exactly how can someone patent Hebbian learning anyway? Aren t patents  supposed to contain/define

Derek James wrote:

>--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>True, I shouldn't jump to conclusions without
>>knowing about the
>>patent, but as you know lots of things get patented
>>that aren't
>>necessarily useful.  And in this field, it's
>>especially unlikely that
>>something is useful just because it's original,
>>since there are a
>>million mediocre variations of implementations that
>>haven't been
>>patented yet. 
>>    
>>
>
>Exactly.  I think the initial conclusions you jumped
>to were just fine, Ken.
>  
>
:) I haven't had chance to do the thorough P.I. job you seem to be doing 
Derek but from what you've said it all sounds a bit odd. Exactly how can 
someone patent Hebbian learning anyway? Aren't patents  supposed to 
contain/define something that is unique and distinct from what has been 
done before. Mind you I hear that patent systems around the world are 
reaching meltdown because of all the spurious applications from 
technolgy firms - no-one at the patent offices is qualified enough to 
judge all of the stuff that gets submitted. The people who ARE qualified 
are the ones generating the submissions :)

>"Francisco holds an A.B. in Biochemistry and a Ph.D.
>in Organismal and Evolutionary Biology, both from
>Harvard, and has three years of postdoctoral
>experience at the Institute of Molecular Evolutionary
>Genetics. He is the author of fifteen publications in
>topflight scientific journals, and his research has
>achieved international attention in the popular as
>well as the scientific press and has been described in
>numerous textbooks."
>  
>
Impressive stuff. Organismal is my word for the day. I will try and work 
into into a conversation somehow.

>Although there are no references or links to any of
>these publications, and Citeseer and other on-line
>searches turn up zilch.
>
Put his name into google. There are some online papers linked from his 
CV at http://www.neuroblast.net/cuvi.html
Everything seems present and correct.

>Right now I'm viewing Ayala, his credentials, and his
>claims with a very large dose of skepticism.
>  
>
Nothing wrong with a healthy dose of skepticism, it is the basis of 
scientific discovery after all. I suspect you may be jumping the gun 
though, I'm sure he's a thouroughly nice chap.

Colin
